Ghodsinia Writing – review & editing Visualization Parvin Sanati-Tirgan Writing – original draft Validation Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad 9177948974, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science Ferdowsi University of Mashhad Mashhad 9177948974 Iran Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad 9177948974, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. In this study, ZnGlu MOF has been immobilized into hexagonal mesoporous silica SBA-16 to fabricate ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 hybrid material. The prepared hybrid material was introduced as a sustainable green nanocomposite for CO2 epoxidation to cyclic carbonates under solvent-free conditions at low pressure of CO2 (5 bar). The structure of the obtained nanocomposites is authenticated using various analytical techniques like FT-IR, XRD, SAXRD, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, BET, TEM, FE-SEM, EDX, EDX-mapping, and ICP-OES. For making a greener process, ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite showed remarkable catalytic activity for converting CO2 with diverse epoxides toward five-membered cyclic carbonates prepared without using any toxic metals and reagents. The presence of the mesoporous silica SBA-16 has improved reactants diffusion and molecular accessibility for suitable interactions in Lewis acid centers, which led to MOFs outperforming in the efficient chemical fixation of CO2. Also, the essential role of free amino groups in ZnGlu MOF was shown as base sites and H-bonding groups when suggesting a possible reaction mechanism. This efficient, and convenient catalytic system can be separated by filtration, and its original activity was maintained for five successive cycles under the same reaction conditions. The above nanocomposite, with great potential, can be used to catalyze different chemical reactions for industrial purposes. Graphical abstract This study reports a solvent-free chemical fixation of carbon dioxide with various epoxides by ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite as an energy-efficient, reusable, and eco-friendly green catalytic system. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous silica SBA-16 ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 hybrid material CO2 fixation Cyclic carbonates Data availability I have shared a link to supporting file of this article. 1 Introduction For environmental health, and economic development, clever planning management is essential. Increasing anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, in turn, cause the greenhouse effect and abnormal climate change on the earth. To CO2 level reduction in the atmosphere, several strategies have been introduced, including CO2 capture and storage (CCS) technologies such as absorption (metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)), membranes for gas separation, and storage of CO2 in the deep ocean [1–8]. Despite this fact, CO2 can be considered a renewable source of carbon that can be utilized as the nontoxic C1-carbon source to produce numerous value-added organic fine chemicals such as dimethyl carbonates, formic acid, methane, lactones, and cyclic carbonates [9–14]. Among these products, the incorporating of carbon dioxide into epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates has an essential inscription in organic synthesis. The five-membered cyclic carbonates are attractive due to their great potential in industrial applications, such as electrolyte solvent in lithium-ion batteries, crude materials in paints and resins, environmentally aprotic solvents and intermediates for many reactions, and as precursors for polymer synthesis [15–21]. Numerous efficient catalysts, including covalent organic frameworks (COFs), metal oxides, porous carbons, porous metal oxides, zeolitic imidazole frameworks, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been published which can act efficiently for significant CO2 reduction [22–26]. MOFs are classified as polymers that are formed between metal ions (as nodes) and bridging ligands (as linkers) by self-assembly [27,28]. The exceptional range of controllable characteristics of MOFs such as high level of porosity, exceptionally large surface area, rich chemical functionality, finely tunable pore, and high adsorption affinity of them, have attracted great attention to themselves as modern multifunctional materials. MOFs can be consequently considered ideal candidates for CO2 fixation reactions due to their phenomenal adsorption properties, gas storage, and Lewis acidic metal site [29–37]. Ordered mesoporous silicas are a group of porous siliceous materials with a high specific surface area, superior hydrothermal stability, and high pore volume [38–41], that can promote catalytic performance by enhancing the dispersion of a diversity of guests like active species derived from metal-organic frameworks [42–48]. Mesoporous hard silica materials such as SBA-16 with hexagonal symmetry can render proper support for dispersing various metal and oxide nanoparticles. The combination of mesoporous SBA-16 and the microporous MOF can lead to the enhanced mechanical, chemical stability of the MOF particles, improvement of gas adsorption behavior, and progresses in the performance of MOF/mesoporous silica hybrid materials. In terms of catalytic application, formed MOF composites through the immobilization of MOF particles into silicates exhibit some superior features of both components [49]. Metal-organic frameworks based on natural amino acids (such as l-Glutamic acid (L-Glu)) with the co-existence of Lewis acidic metals (such as Zn), base sites, and H-bonding groups are employed as organic linkers. It is expected, the combination of ZnGlu MOF with SBA-16 taking advantage of the characteristics of both components, can fabricate a new hybrid material that would present promising performance toward CO2 adsorption at ambient conditions. For this purpose, nanocrystals of ZnGlu MOF have been grown inside the hexagonal arrangement of mesopores of SBA-16 (Scheme 1 ). Keeping these points in mind, herein we report the construction, characterization, and catalytic activity of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite towards solvent-free fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under 5 bar CO2 pressure. This catalytic system can be conveniently separated upon applying simple filtration, and efficiently recycled at least five times without significant changes. Notably that ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16, with considerable advantages, can be accelerate the chemical reaction for industrial purposes as an environmentally friendly nanocatalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 General All chemicals and solvents were used as received without any further purification and were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich.The obtained products were purified by column chromatography d by thin-layer chromatography. 2.2 Preparation of mesoporous silica SBA-16 The preparation of mesoporous silica SBA-16 was successfully prepared by the previously report in the literature [50]. In brief, 1.484 g of Pluronic F127 and 0.238 g of P123 polymer were completely dispersed in a solution of 8.87 mL concentrated HCl to 70 mL of deionized water. After being magnetically stirred at 35 °C for 4 h, 5.22 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added into the resulting solution, and magnetically stirred was kept on for 40 min. Afterward, the obtained suspension was transferred into a Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave and kept under static conditions for 24 h at 35 °C. Thereupon, the temperature was increased to 100 °C and kept for 32 h. Subsequently, the precipitate was filtered and dried at room temperature in low air humidity. The as-synthesized SBA-16 material was calcinated in the air at 550 °C for 10 h to P127 and P123 polymers removal. 2.3 Synthesis of ZnGlu MOF Synthesis of zinc-glutamate MOF was based on the procedure reported by the literature method. Typically, 0.294 g (2 mmol) of l-Glutamic acid and 0.575 g (2 mmol) of ZnSO4·7H2O, and 0.200 g (5 mmol) of NaOH were dissolved in an aqueous solution at room temperature. The readily white precipitate was obtained by filtration and ZnGlu MOF was obtained after drying under a vacuum overnight. 2.4 Synthesis of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 0.1 g of calcined SBA-16 is dispersed in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) for 15 min. Then, ZnSO4·7H2O (2 mmol) solution as metal precursor, and l-Glutamic acid (2 mmol) as organic linker were added to the mixture to complete the MOF precursors. The resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. Then, ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 was centrifuged and, washed several times with DMF and ethanol, and vacuum dried at 90 °C overnight. 2.5 Catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides The coupling of carbon dioxide with epoxides to formation of cyclic carbonates was achieved in a 50 mL high-pressure stainless-steel reactor containing a magnetic stirrer bar. The reactor was charged with a mixture of epoxy styrene (8 mmol, 1.312 g), and TBAB (0.5 mmol, 0.016 g) in the presence of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocatalyst (0.05 g, 8.8 mol % Zn). The sealed reactor was heated to 80 °C under 5 bar CO2 pressure on a stirring/hot plate. When the reaction was completed, the vessel was cooled to a lower temperature, and CO2 was slowly delivered from the reactor. After separating the nanocatalyst by simple filtration, and washing it with ethyl acetate (3 × 10 mL), the nanocatalyst was dried at 70 °C overnight for the next run. The product was extracted with ethyl acetate and then purified by column chromatography using ethyl acetate/hexane (3: 10) to afford the pure desired product (0.158 g, 97 % yield). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The FT-IR spectroscopy of the ZnGlu MOF (a), SBA-16 (b), and ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite (c) was illustrated in Fig. 1 . The appearance of two absorption bands in the regions 1621 and 1415 cm−1 (related to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of carboxylate groups) can confirm the successful synthesis of ZnGlu MOF (Fig. 1a). Moreover, the apperceived broad absorption bands from 3456 to 2962 cm−1 which associated with the stretching vibration of NH and OH bonds, demonstrating the presence of NH2 groups (3300 cm−1) and the coordinated water molecules in the ZnGlu MOF structure [51]. In addition, the band at 610 cm−1 was assigned as a stretching vibration of Zn-O in the MOF structure (Fig. 1a). The characteristic absorption bands of SBA-16 appeared at 1087, 811, and 460 cm−1 which is related to the bending vibrations and modes of asymmetric, symmetric, of Si–O–Si stretching (Fig. 1b). The existence of two typical adsorption bands at 3430 cm−1 (broad absorption band) and 1630 cm−1 are allocated to the bending and stretching modes of the adsorbed water molecules and surface-attached hydroxyl groups (Si–OH), respectively. Furthermore, Fig. 1b displays the absorption bands in the range of 1200–1100 cm−1 associated with the stretching vibration of Si–O–Si, which is overlapped with Si–C and Si–O–C bonds. The well-synthesized SBA-16 was corroborated by the advent of a specific band at 965 cm−1, related to the stretching vibration of the Si–OH bond [52]. After completing the SBA-16 composite process with ZnGlu MOF, the FT-IR diagram of the nanocomposite manifested the presence of distinctive peaks of both parent materials. In addition, the diminish at intensity of vibrational frequencies of surface-attached hydroxyl groups (Si–OH) in SBA-16 and amino groups in ZnGlu MOF, which is visible in the region of 2906–3469 cm−1, indicated the successful growth of ZnGlu MOF along with SBA-16 (Fig. 1c). Also, the corresponding peaks of carboxylate groups coordinated with zinc metal in ZnGlu MOF, which were assigned to 1407 and 1614 cm−1, confirmed that the changes in the intensity of these peaks can be related to the changes in the environment around the carboxylate ligand. On the other hand, the advent of the peak located at 1105 cm−1 was related to the CO bond in the ZnGlu MOF structure and the Si-O-Si bond in SBA-16. Also, it can be seen that the peak of Zn-O was slightly shifted from 610 to 620 cm−1 due to the interaction of ZnGlu MOF with SBA-16. This is an indication that ZnGlu MOF has been successfully composited with SBA-16. which was another evidence for the successful formation of the synthesized nanocomposite. Finally, the stretching vibration of Si-O-Si bonds (806 cm−1) in the final nanocatalyst structure was still maintained, while the peak intensity was reduced. We used the X-ray diffraction (XRD), in order to provide information on unit cell dimensions and identify the phase of the crystalline material, as a rapid technique. Fig. 2 exposes the XRD schema of single crystal simulated ZnGlu MOF (a), ZnGlu MOF(b), SBA-16 (c) in comparison with the pattern of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 (d) to confirm the crystalline structure of the prepared nanocatalyst. The powder XRD pattern of the synthesized ZnGlu MOF sample was well-matched with the peaks in the simulated pattern (Fig. 2a and b), although the relative peak intensities were different, strongly suggesting that they represent the same phase [53,54]. As can be inferred from Fig. 2c, the observation of broad peaks at 2θ = 15°–35° proves the amorphous structure of SBA-16, and the obtained patterns are completely consistent with the pattern reported in the literature [52]. Moreover, the PXRD pattern of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 composite (Fig. 2d), revealed that it is composed of two phases, which include crystalline (ZnGlu MOF) and amorphous structure (SBA-16). During the composition process, the decrease in the intensity of the peak can be due to the filling of the pores of SBA-16, which confirms that the crystal structure of pure ZnGlu MOF changes after merging with SBA-16. The small-angle X-ray diffraction (SAXRD) technique was provided to gain further insight into the structural properties of the pristine SBA-16. As can be evident from Fig. 2f, the SAXRD pattern of the pure SBA-16 exhibits two diffraction peaks at 2θ = 0.53 ° and 0.90 ° indexed to the (1 1 0), and (2 0 0) planes, respectively. These planes are characteristic of the 3D-hexagonal arrangement of mesoporous materials [55]. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) technique is powerful and effective in obtaining information about surface chemistry. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) technique was performed to determine the strength of surface basic sites for the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, the appearance of a steep peak at around 395 °C was attributed to strong basic sites (NH2 group in ZnGlu MOF). NH3 can be applied as a probe molecule to explore the overall acid properties of the catalyst surface using NH3-TPD. Thus, NH3-TPD profiles for the tested catalysts (Fig. 3b) showed strong and weak acid sites with different acid strengths. The one at 150–230 °C could be attributed to the weak adsorption of the NH3 on the Brønsted acid sites and NH3 association with the Si–OH group, and the sharp peak at 390 °C could be ascribed to strong desorption of NH3 adsorbed on the acidic sites of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite surface/structure [56]. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, and pore structure of the synthesized nanocomposite are among the most important factors affecting the catalytic activity. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis of SBA-16 (a), ZnGlu MOF (b), and ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite (c), were investigated in order to obtain more discernment into the textural properties (BET surface areas and the pore-size distributions) (Figs. 4 a-e). The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of SBA-16 exhibits typical type IV isotherm with the appearance of the H2-type hysteresis loops at a relative pressure which is associated with the presence of the mesoporous cage-like structure (Fig. 4a). The average surface areas and pore volumes of pure SBA-16 (I) are around 525 m2 g − 1 and 0.575 cm3 g − 1, respectively (Table 1 ). As can be seen in Fig. 4b, N2 adsorption-desorption curve ZnGlu MOF is a typical type- IV adsorption isotherm. There is hysteresis in the curve after P/P0 > 0.3, which indicates the capillary condensation process, and the isotherm steeply rises. The two branches of the adsorption-desorption curve are basically parallel within a certain P/P0 range and form an obvious H3-type lag loop, which belongs to the IV-type curve. Furthermore, the derived BET surface area and pore volume are approximated to be 42 m2 g − 1 and 0.105 cm3 g − 1, respectively. Moreover, investigating the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution, which was calculated using the adsorption branch, (Fig. 4e) clearly shows a peak centered at 2.21 nm, corresponding to the mesoporous ZnGlu MOF. As it is beheld from the diagram observed in this analysis and the studies conducted in Table 1, the BET surface area of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite is larger than the pure ZnGlu MOF (Fig. 4c). The larger pore volume of the nanocomposite in comparison to the pure MOF proposed a specific mesoporous structure, providing a suitable pathway for mass transport (Table 1). The lag phenomenon occurs earlier than that of SBA-16 and later than that of ZnGlu MOF. Thus, for SBA-16 the presence of ZnGlu MOF reduces the pore size, while for ZnGlu MOF, the presence of SBA-16 increases the number of mesopores. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the presence of ZnGlu MOF affects the size of SBA-16 pores suggesting partial filling of the mesopores by ZnGlu MOF, and the absorption capacity of nitrogen molecules decreases in the synthesized nanocomposite structure, which is entirely following the results of the electron microscope [57]. This observation could indicate the growth of the MOF inside the mesopore SBA-16 rather than outside. Albeit, the TEM image (Fig. 5 d) exhibits limited MOFs to be present outside the SBA matrix and most of the MOFs must be present inside the SBA-16 channel. As well, the excellent regularity of the nanocomposite was proved by BJH calculations of nanocomposite which displayed a high-intensity peak with uniform pore size distribution (Fig. 4d). In order to investigate the morphology of the synthesized nanocomposite, SEM and TEM analyses of the compounds were carried out. It is evident from Fig. 5a that the as-prepared SBA-16 exhibited spherical morphology with sizes ranging from 2 to 8 µm along with good dispersity. SBA-16 has a distinct spherical structure with a smooth surface. Also, ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite also has a spherical structure, albeit appearing as an accumulation of the structures with a rough surface on the surface of SBA-16 indicating the spherical morphology of SBA-16 has almost remained during the synthesis process (Fig. 5b). As can be seen, the SBA −16 morphology plays an important role in the morphological characteristics of the nanocomposite. To take a closer look, the hexagonal regularity of monotonous channels of the as-synthesized SBA-16 was recorded by TEM analysis (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, TEM image of nanocomposite shows not only are most of the channels of SBA-16 occupied by the formation of the nanocrystals of MOFs, but also the distributions are approximately even (Fig. 5d). EDX detector equipped with SEM instrument is a device for determining the elemental composition of the sample, which in this particular case of the synthesized ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite proves the presence of C, N, O, Si, and Zn elements (Fig. 5e). In addition, EDX-mapping data was performed for further analysis of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite and the results are shown in Fig. 5f. This analysis confirmed the elements in the nanocomposite correctly and in complete agreement with the EDX data. 3.2 Catalytic performance of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite The catalytic efficiency of the prepared ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite was explored in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 (as an alternative to toxic reagents such as phosgene) into epoxides by adding a catalytic amount of co-catalyst tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) (Scheme 2 ). To obtain information on the optimum reaction conditions and role of the catalyst, the chemical fixation of CO2 with styrene oxide (SO) was chosen as a model reaction. Several factors, such as solvent, catalyst loading, base, and temperature, were investigated to optimize the reaction conditions (Table 2 ). In early studies, the catalytic role of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 under solvent-free conditions at 110 °C, and 10 bar CO2 pressure in the presence of 8 mmol of styrene oxide was applied to evaluate efficient synthetic CO2 fixation. In conducting the cycloaddition of CO2 with SO in the absence of TBAB, was not observed corresponding product even when the reaction time increased (Table 2, entry 1). In the later test, the styrene carbonate (SC) via the fixation of CO2 was prepared using ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 in the absence of TBAB under the same reaction conditions, and this result approximately shows ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 can alone act as a standalone catalyst at high temperatures and pressure (Table 2, entry 2). This could be ascribed to the presence of the nucleophilic anions of the MOF for epoxide ring opening, which is crucial in the ring opening of epoxide by CO2 molecules. It is notable that ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 in the presence of TBAB leads to the carbonate product after a short reaction time (Table 2, entry 3). Next, the effect of DMSO, DMF, toluene, CH2Cl2, H2O as a solvent, and solvent-free conditions was investigated toward the related product (Tables 2, entries 3–8). In the midst of investigated solvents, the desired product was obtained with an appreciable yield under solvent-free conditions (Tables 2, entry 3). As catalyst loading plays a crucial role in optimizing product yields and increasing the rate of the reaction, to find the efficient amount of catalyst, the model reaction was carried out in the presence of 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, and 0.07 g of the nanocomposite (Table 2, entries 9–11). In comparison, using 0.05 g of catalyst reveal an increase in the yield of the product (Table 2, entry 10). Nevertheless, the low amount of catalyst (0.01 g) led to the reduction of the desired product yield (Table 2, entry 9). While applying more of the catalyst, to 0.07, was unaffected on the yield of the desired product formation (Table 2, entry 11). The effect of temperature on the forming of cyclic carbonate was also studied. The best reaction outcome was achieved at 80°C (Table 2, entries 11–15). After a few attempts to determine the best of the pressure of CO2 (Table 2, entries 14, and 16–19), it was attained the maximum yield of the desired product under 5 bar pressure (97 % after 3 h) (Table 2, entry 19). After all, by comparing the performance of SBA-16, and ZnGlu MOF as nanocatalysts in the model reaction, the catalytic performance of the fabrication of microporous metal–organic frameworks was further corroborated (Table 2, entries 20, and 21). In order to understand, whether the presence of SBA-16 in the combination with ZnGlu MOF, plays a significant role in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, this study also investigated the aim of catalytic behaviors SBA-16, and ZnGlu MOf comparing ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 (Table 2, entries 22, and 23). It is evident that the mesopore channels of SBA-16 facilitate easier diffusion of reactant molecules and catalytic interactions (Table 2, entry 22). Then, the performance of the mechanical combination of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 with the same molar ratio of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 composite was studied under the same optimal conditions. Not surprisingly, the desired product by mechanical combination was obtained with a lower yield, which could be the result of the fact that some reactant molecules are easily trapped in the cages of SBA-16, and results in fewer of them being exposed to Lewis acid/base sites of Zn GluMOF. This observation can confirm the importance of the composite process of a combination of ZnGlu MOF with SBA-16 (Table 2, entry 24). It was observed that the highest yield of the cyclic carbonate production from epoxide with CO2 was comparatively obtained due to the synergistic effect of suitable acidity/basicity that mesoporosity of catalyst plays an important role in promoting diffusion and accessibility to active sites. The efficiency of the catalytic approach in the present method was led to the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide into diversity of substrate scope of epoxides toward the best yield of the coupling products (Table 3 , entries 1–7). It is evident from Table 3 that CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates with epichlorohydrin, including the electron-withdrawing group, produced the desired cyclic carbonate in short times with high isolated yields (Table 3, entries 1 & 6). However, good activity of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocatalyst was observed toward internal epoxide with a high steric hindrance effect leading to the production of corresponding cyclic carbonate (Table 3, entry 7). Besides, the structure elucidation of the products was determined using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy as the prime technique (supporting information). On the basis of previously reported literature for MOF-catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [58], a proposed catalytic mechanism can be proposed based on Lewis acid sites to activation of the epoxides for ring opening, and nucleophilic anion to facilitate CO2 insertion with TBAB cocatalyst (Scheme 3 ). At first, the oxygen of the epoxy ring is activated by the Lewis acid sites, or by forming an H-bond by free NH2 and carboxylic groups of the nanocomposite (intermediate I). Concomitantly, the activated epoxide is opened by the nucleophilic attack of bromide ions of TBAB molecule on the less sterically hindered epoxide side, leading to the insertion of polarized CO2 molecules (the −NH2 groups as Lewis base activated the CO2 molecule via forming a carbamate salt). Also, the CO2 molecules that diffuse into mesopores of SBA-16 help enhance interaction with reactant molecules (intermediate II). In the following, the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of the polarized CO2 to β-carbon led to the ring-opened epoxide, forming an intermediate III (with the elimination of bromine anion). Finally, the cyclic carbonate (IV) was formed by intramolecular ring closure, and the regenerated nanocatalyst moves to the next catalytic cycle. Lewis acid sites (Zn), Lewis base sites (−NH2 groups), and hydrogen bonds (HB) between the hydroxyl/amino group of the catalyst and the oxygen atom of epoxides play important roles in promoting the CO2 cycloaddition reaction to cyclic carbonate. According to the proposed plausible catalytic mechanism in Scheme 3, the satisfactory catalytic performance of nanocomposite catalyst resulted from the Lewis base amino groups, HBD groups (-COOH and -NH2), Lewis acid Zn center, and nucleophile component TBAB. Also, the CO2 was activated to form the carbamate intermediate by −NH2 group as Lewis base (under optimized reaction conditions), which was also confirmed by FT-IR spectra (1793 cm−1) (Fig. 6 b) [59,60]. 3.3 Reusability study of the catalyst Considering the environmental and economic-related importance of CO2 fixation reactions, the efficient reusability of the heterogeneous catalyst is considered a serious requirement. In this aspect, to test the reusability and regenerability of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocatalyst, the model reaction was performed under optimizing reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 17). The performance evaluation has been demonstrated in Fig. 7 . In brief, upon completion of the reaction in each run, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. Nanocatalyst was separated by simple filtration, washed with diluted ethyl acetate (3 × 5 mL), and dried under vacuum at 70 °C overnight for removing residual organic solvents for use in the next execution. As can be seen in Fig. 7, no obvious loss in performance after five consecutive runs, indicating reasonably good durability of the nanocomposite in the CO2 fixation reaction. The recyclability and stability of the ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite, after five successive cycloadditions of CO2 to styrene oxide, was evaluated. To investigate the structural changes of nanocatalyst, FT-IR, PXRD, and ICP-OES techniques were used. The peak positions, frequencies, intensities, and shapes of all absorption bands in the FT-IR spectrum of 5th reused nanocomposite, are well-preserved (Fig. 1d). Furthermore, by comparing the curve presented in Fig. 2e, the XRD pattern of the 5th reused ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite indicated the same positions of the XRD pattern, and no significant differences were observed compared to the XRD pattern of orginal samples (Fig. 2d). However, a very slight decrease in the intensity of the peaks was seen, which can be due to the filling metal-organic framework mesopores with the organic motifs. Also, the ICP-OES method was applied to determine the amounts of Zn in the fresh and the 5th reused ZnGlu MOF /SBA-16 nanocomposite. According to the achieved data, the freshly prepared nanostructure is consisting of 1.8 mmol (0.05 g, 8.8 mol %) of Zn, and after recycling 5 times nanocatalyst 1.79 mmol of zinc per 1.000 g the nanocatalyst. This difference is not distinct and can be ignored. By knowing the efficiency of the prepared nanocatalyst, its catalytic performance with some reported catalyst systems in the literature was compared in the fixation of carbon dioxide with epoxides under different catalytic conditions (Table 4 ). It is reputed that almost all the mentioned catalysts show high yields of desired products. However, it is seen that ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite as an efficient nanostructured catalyst is more efficient than almost all the catalytic systems reported in Table 4. As shown in Table 4, the main drawbacks of the homogeneous catalytic system are recovery and reusability for further cycles and separation from the reaction mixture (Table 4, entry 5). As we1l as, the long reaction time (Table 4, entries 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7), higher pressure of CO2 (Table 4, entries 4–6), and low product yields (Table 4, entries 4 and 5) are the disadvantages of some of these methods. ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite offers different advantages as compared to various defects of the reported systems in the CO2 fixation reaction, such as a sufficient yield in a shorter reaction time, simple separation, milder reaction conditions, easy preparation of the catalyst, economic costs, and common environmental concerns. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed a novel ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 hybrid material by dispersing ZnGluMOF precursors into hexagonal mesoporous silica SBA-16 that revealed an interesting potential catalytic pathway toward the synthesis of the cyclic carbonates from various epoxides with CO2 under solvent-free reaction conditions. The characterization results of the as-synthesized nanocatalyst by several optical spectroscopic and microscopic techniques (FT-IR, XRD, SAXRD, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, BET, TEM, FE-SEM, EDX, and ICP-OES) were confirmed. The hybrid nature of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 offers quick diffusion and easy accessibility of reactants to Lewis acid sites along with amine groups of the nanocomposite. This nanocatalyst was separable by simple filtration and its framework was not degraded even after five recurrences of the cycles, which promisingly no reduction has appeared in the conversion rate of the cycloaddition. coredata.dc:description: In this study, ZnGlu MOF has been immobilized into hexagonal mesoporous silica SBA-16 to fabricate ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 hybrid material. The prepared hybrid material was introduced as a sustainable green nanocomposite for CO2 epoxidation to cyclic carbonates under solvent-free conditions at low pressure of CO2 (5 bar). The structure of the obtained nanocomposites is authenticated using various analytical techniques like FT-IR, XRD, SAXRD, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, BET, TEM, FE-SEM, EDX, EDX-mapping, and ICP-OES. For making a greener process, ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite showed remarkable catalytic activity for converting CO2 with diverse epoxides toward five-membered cyclic carbonates prepared without using any toxic metals and reagents. The presence of the mesoporous silica SBA-16 has improved reactants diffusion and molecular accessibility for suitable interactions in Lewis acid centers, which led to MOFs outperforming in the efficient chemical fixation of CO2. Also, the essential role of free amino groups in ZnGlu MOF was shown as base sites and H-bonding groups when suggesting a possible reaction mechanism. This efficient, and convenient catalytic system can be separated by filtration, and its original activity was maintained for five successive cycles under the same reaction conditions. The above nanocomposite, with great potential, can be used to catalyze different chemical reactions for industrial purposes.
coredata.dc:title: Design and synthesis of ZnGlu MOF/SBA-16 nanocomposite, and its performance as an environmentally friendly nanocomposite for solvent-free chemical fixation of CO2 to epoxides for high-yield synthesis of cyclic carbonates
